in.tamchow.fractal.helpers.math

Class MersenneTwister

  • java.lang.Object
    • in.tamchow.fractal.helpers.math.MersenneTwister
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable

    public class MersenneTwister
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable
    A PseudoRandom Number Generator (PRNG) based on the Mersenne Twister algorithm.
    This does not guarantee concurrent usability of a single instance as no methods are synchronized.

    Adapted from: Sean Luke's Fast Mersenne Twister

    1. Methods are hard-inlined for speed as in the original.
    2. Modern documentation comments are my contribution.
    3. Ranged random methods are also my contribution

      • MersenneTwister

        public MersenneTwister()
        Constructor using the default seed.

      • MersenneTwister

        public MersenneTwister(long seed)
        Constructor using a given seed. Though you pass this seed in as a long, it's best to make sure it's actually an integer.
        Parameters:
        seed - the seed of this PRNG
        See Also:
        setSeed(long)

      • MersenneTwister

        public MersenneTwister(int[] array)
        Constructor using an array of integers as seed. Your array must have a non-zero length. Only the first 624 integers in the array are used; if the array is shorter than this then integers are repeatedly used in a wrap-around fashion.
        Parameters:
        array - the seed of this PRNG
        See Also:
        setSeed(int[])

    • Method Detail

      • clone

        public java.lang.Object clone()
        We're overriding all internal data, to my knowledge, so this should be okay
        Overrides:
        clone in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        a clone of this MersenneTwister as an Object

      • stateEquals

        public boolean stateEquals(MersenneTwister other)
        Returns true if this MersenneTwister's current internal state is equal to another MersenneTwister. That another is other.
        This is roughly the same as Object.equals(Object), except that it compares based on value but does not guarantee the contract of immutability (obviously random number generators are immutable).
        Note that this does NOT check to see if the internal gaussian storage is the same for both.
        You can guarantee that the internal Gaussian storage is the same (and so the nextGaussian() methods will return the same values) by calling clearGaussian() on both objects.
        Parameters:
        other - the MersenneTwister to compare with this
        Returns:
        true if the state of other is the same as this, false otherwise

      • readState

        public void readState(java.io.DataInputStream stream)
               throws java.io.IOException
        Reads the entire state of the MersenneTwister RNG from the stream
        Parameters:
        stream - the DataInputStream to load the MersenneTwister from.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - on any I/O error

      • writeState

        public void writeState(java.io.DataOutputStream stream)
                throws java.io.IOException
        Writes the entire state of the MersenneTwister RNG to the stream
        Parameters:
        stream - the DataOutputStream to write this MersenneTwister to.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - on any I/O error

      • setSeed

        public void setSeed(long seed)
        Initialize the pseudo random number generator. Don't pass in a long that's bigger than an int (Mersenne Twister only uses the first 32 bits for its seed).
        Parameters:
        seed - the seed for this PRNG

      • setSeed

        public void setSeed(int[] array)
        Sets the seed of the MersenneTwister using an array of integers. Your array must have a non-zero length. Only the first 624 integers in the array are used; if the array is shorter than this then integers are repeatedly used in a wrap-around fashion.
        Parameters:
        array - the seed for this PRNG

      • nextInt

        public int nextInt()
        Returns:
        a random integer drawn uniformly from 0 to Integer.MAX_VALUE

      • nextShort

        public short nextShort()
        Returns:
        a random short value drawn uniformly from 0 to Short.MAX_VALUE

      • nextChar

        public char nextChar()
        Returns:
        a random UTF-16 character as an char value drawn uniformly from '\0' to Character.MAX_VALUE

      • nextBoolean

        public boolean nextBoolean()
        Simulates a fair coin toss.
        Returns:
        a boolean with equal probability of either true or false

      • nextBoolean

        public boolean nextBoolean(double probability)
        This generates a coin flip with a probability probability of returning true, else returning false.
        Parameters:
        probability - the probability of returning true
        Returns:
        true or false as regards the probability
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if probability is not between 0.0 and 1.0, inclusive

      • nextByte

        public byte nextByte()
        Returns:
        a random byte value drawn uniformly from 0 to Byte.MAX_VALUE

      • nextLong

        public long nextLong()
        Returns:
        a long drawn uniformly from 0 to Long.MAX_VALUE-1

      • nextLong

        public long nextLong(long min,
                     long max)
        Parameters:
        min - the lower limit
        max - the upper limit
        Returns:
        a long drawn uniformly from min to max-1.

      • nextLong

        public long nextLong(long n)
        Parameters:
        n - the upper limit
        Returns:
        a long drawn uniformly from 0 to n-1.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if n < 0

      • nextDouble

        public double nextDouble(double min,
                         double max)
        Parameters:
        min - the lower limit
        max - the upper limit
        Returns:
        random double in the range min and max

      • nextDouble

        public double nextDouble()
        Returns:
        a random double in the half-open range from [0.0,1.0). Thus, 0.0 is a valid result, but 1.0 is not.

      • nextDouble

        public double nextDouble(boolean includeZero,
                         boolean includeOne)
        Returns a double in the range from 0.0 to 1.0, possibly inclusive of 0.0 and 1.0 themselves. Thus:
        ExpressionInterval
        nextDouble(false, false)(0.0, 1.0)
        nextDouble(true, false)[0.0, 1.0)
        nextDouble(false, true)(0.0, 1.0]
        nextDouble(true, true)[0.0, 1.0]
        Table of intervals

        This version preserves all possible random values in the double range.

        Parameters:
        includeOne - whether to include 1.0d
        includeZero - whether to include 0.0d
        Returns:
        an double in the range [0.0, 1.0], (0.0, 1.0), [0.0, 1.0) or (0.0,1.0] as above.

      • clearGaussian

        public void clearGaussian()
        Clears the internal gaussian variable from the RNG. You only need to do this in the rare case that you need to guarantee that two RNGs have identical internal state. Otherwise, disregard this method.
        See Also:
        stateEquals(MersenneTwister)

      • nextGaussian

        public double nextGaussian()
        Returns:
        a random double value in a Gaussian distribution

      • nextFloat

        public float nextFloat(float min,
                       float max)
        Parameters:
        min - the lower limit
        max - the upper limit
        Returns:
        random float in the range min and max

      • nextFloat

        public float nextFloat()
        Returns:
        a random float in the half-open range from [0.0f,1.0f). Thus 0.0f is a valid result but 1.0f is not.

      • nextFloat

        public float nextFloat(boolean includeZero,
                       boolean includeOne)
        Returns a float in the range from 0.0f to 1.0f, possibly inclusive of 0.0f and 1.0f themselves. Thus:
        ExpressionInterval
        nextFloat(false, false)(0.0f, 1.0f)
        nextFloat(true, false)[0.0f, 1.0f)
        nextFloat(false, true)(0.0f, 1.0f]
        nextFloat(true, true)[0.0f, 1.0f]
        Table of intervals

        This version preserves all possible random values in the float range.

        Parameters:
        includeOne - whether to include 1.0f
        includeZero - whether to include 0.0f
        Returns:
        an float in the range [0.0, 1.0], (0.0, 1.0), [0.0, 1.0) or (0.0,1.0] as above.
